    Frog-armed: A first encounter with data

    casestudy-1st_encounter_w_data_a_summary_stats-FROGARMS.Rmd
    library(compbio4all)

    Preliminaries

    Load packagtes

    library(wildlifeR)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'wildlifeR'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:compbio4all':
#> 
#>     combine_NLCD_classes, expand_BBS_routes, make_my_data2L,
#>     NA_to_zero, sample_BBS_routes, sample_dove_routes
library(ggplot2)
library(cowplot)
library(ggpubr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'ggpubr'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:cowplot':
#> 
#>     get_legend
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

    Load data

    data(frogarms)

    Subset your data

    The function make_my_data2L() will extact out a random subset of the data. Change “my.code” to your school email address, minus the “@pitt.edu” or whatever your affiliation is.

    my.frogs <- make_my_data2L(dat = frogarms, 
                           my.code = "nlb24", # <=  change this!
                           cat.var = "sex",
                           n.sample = 20, 
                           with.rep = FALSE)
#> Codes should only contain letters and numbers
#> Your special code is  4782969
#> (You don't really need to know this, though). 4782969
#> NOTE: This function only works properly for data with TWO levels to the categorical var.
#>  eg male vs. female; it doesn't work for >2 levels (eg red vs blue vs. green)

    n.sample is set to 20. This is set up to extract 20 unique individuals of each sex. Check that you dataframe is 2*20 = 40 rows using the dim() command.

    dim(my.frogs)
#> [1] 40  8

    A 1st encounter with R: getting to know your data

    dim(my.frogs)
#> [1] 40  8
nrow(my.frogs)
#> [1] 40
ncol(my.frogs)
#> [1] 8
    head(my.frogs)
#>     i.row i.frog    sex mass sv.length forearm  arm i.rows.working
#> 471   471    477 female 2.08     30.64    2.23 2.10            471
#> 440   440    445 female 1.96     30.02      NA   NA            440
#> 472   472    478 female 1.96     30.70    2.06 1.81            472
#> 452   452    458 female 1.23     25.70    1.71 1.68            452
#> 460   460    466 female 4.02     40.47    2.65 2.99            460
#> 450   450    456 female 2.51     33.89    2.42 2.47            450
tail(my.frogs)
#>     i.row i.frog  sex mass sv.length forearm  arm i.rows.working
#> 117   117    118 male 2.82     33.04    3.35 4.46            117
#> 297   297    301 male 3.34     34.71    4.53 5.60            297
#> 251   251    252 male 3.82     35.64    4.81 5.65            251
#> 185   185    186 male 2.71     32.32    3.30 4.18            185
#> 101   101    102 male 2.05     31.36    3.14 3.58            101
#> 288   288    292 male 5.92     40.97    5.08 7.75            288
    names(my.frogs)
#> [1] "i.row"          "i.frog"         "sex"            "mass"          
#> [5] "sv.length"      "forearm"        "arm"            "i.rows.working"
    ?my.frogs

    A 1st encounter with R: summary statistics

    R is a giant calcualter

    Overall summary

    Whole dataframe

    summary(my.frogs)
#>      i.row           i.frog          sex          mass         sv.length    
#>  Min.   : 79.0   Min.   : 80.0   female:20   Min.   :0.810   Min.   :23.46  
#>  1st Qu.:180.5   1st Qu.:181.5   male  :20   1st Qu.:1.913   1st Qu.:28.68  
#>  Median :436.0   Median :441.0               Median :2.170   Median :31.55  
#>  Mean   :333.1   Mean   :337.0               Mean   :2.585   Mean   :31.96  
#>  3rd Qu.:461.8   3rd Qu.:467.8               3rd Qu.:3.325   3rd Qu.:34.33  
#>  Max.   :497.0   Max.   :504.0               Max.   :6.680   Max.   :41.77  
#>                                                                             
#>     forearm           arm        i.rows.working 
#>  Min.   :1.160   Min.   :1.460   Min.   : 79.0  
#>  1st Qu.:2.200   1st Qu.:1.988   1st Qu.:180.5  
#>  Median :2.865   Median :3.055   Median :436.0  
#>  Mean   :2.944   Mean   :3.445   Mean   :333.1  
#>  3rd Qu.:3.533   3rd Qu.:4.438   3rd Qu.:461.8  
#>  Max.   :5.220   Max.   :7.750   Max.   :497.0  
#>  NA's   :2       NA's   :2

    Just a single column

    summary(my.frogs$mass)
#>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
#>   0.810   1.913   2.170   2.585   3.325   6.680

    Can compare your subset to the original data

    summary(my.frogs$mass)
#>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
#>   0.810   1.913   2.170   2.585   3.325   6.680
summary(frogarms$mass)
#>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
#>   0.630   1.690   2.290   2.577   3.210   7.040

    Handy trick: stack up the data with rbind()

    rbind(summary(my.frogs$mass),
      summary(frogarms$mass))
#>      Min. 1st Qu. Median     Mean 3rd Qu. Max.
#> [1,] 0.81  1.9125   2.17 2.585250   3.325 6.68
#> [2,] 0.63  1.6900   2.29 2.576994   3.210 7.04

    Individual summary stats

    mean(my.frogs$mass)
#> [1] 2.58525
    var(my.frogs$mass)
#> [1] 1.552323
    • median()
    • min()
    • max()
    • var()
    • sd()
    • range()
    • nrow() or length() (for sample size)

    range() returns two values in a vector

    range(my.frogs$mass)
#> [1] 0.81 6.68

    Note that R doesn’t return a very common statistic, the standard error (SE). This can be calcualted by hand.

    sd(my.frogs$mass)/sqrt(length(my.frogs$mass))
#> [1] 0.1969977

    Write a function

    my_sd1 <- function(dat_column){
sd(dat_column)/sqrt(length(dat_column))
}

my_sd2 <- function(dat, column){
sd(dat[,column])/sqrt(length(dat[,column]))
}


my_sd3 <- function(dat, column, digits.round = 3){
se <- sd(dat[,column])/sqrt(length(dat[,column]))
round(se, digits = digits.round)
}
    my_sd2(dat = my.frogs, column = "mass")
#> [1] 0.1969977

    A 1st encounter with dplyr

    dplyr is a package that provides numerous functions for manipulating data. We will use two handy functions

    • summarize() / summarise()
    • group_by()

    dplyr can use a handy sytax that involes “pipes”. You can string together R commands using the function %>%

    When using pipes, you start with a dataframe and follow it with an action you want done to it. So, for example, previously when we wanted the mean of the mass column we did this

    mean(my.frogs$mass)

    Which is kidn of read like a normal mathematical equation or function, where you start from inside the parentheses and work out. R let’s you nest as many functions as you wnat. If i want to round my mean is wrap “mean(my.frogs$mass)” in round(…)

    round(mean(my.frogs$mass))
#> [1] 3

    Using pipes to get the mean I write things more like a sentence:

    my.frogs$mass %>% mean() #note parentheses.
#> [1] 2.58525

    Which reads kine of like “Take the mass column and the datagrame and apply the mean() function to it.” Note that the parentheses have to be included even though there is nothing in them.

    To round the mean we would do this

    my.frogs$mass %>% mean() %>% round()
#> [1] 3

    Which read left to right like a sentence is “Take the mass column, calcualte the mean and then rond it.”

    Note that the rond() command has an arguement for how many digits you want to round to. You include that in the parantehes

    my.frogs$mass %>% mean() %>% round(digits = 2)
#> [1] 2.59
    dplyr’s summarize() commnad

    INstead of mean(data$column) we can use summarise()/summarize() and pipes Grand mean of mass

    my.frogs %>% summarise(mean(mass))
#>   mean(mass)
#> 1    2.58525

    this is maybe more complicated than “mean(my.frogs$mass)” but overall the pipe framework and summarise pays off when combined with group_b()

    group_by

    For some more info on group_by see

    https://www.r-bloggers.com/using-r-quickly-calculating-summary-statistics-with-dplyr/ https://www3.nd.edu/~steve/computing_with_data/24_dplyr/dplyr.html http://www.datacarpentry.org/R-genomics/04-dplyr.html

    We can use group_by() to slit things up by a categorical variable. Here, we can say “take my.frogs, split up the data by the sex column, and apply the mean function to each subset.”

    my.frogs %>% 
  group_by(sex) %>%
  summarise(mean(mass))
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   sex    `mean(mass)`
#>   <fct>         <dbl>
#> 1 female         2.20
#> 2 male           2.97

    note that the column heading in is mean(mass), which is what is in summarise().

    A handy thing about sumarise is you can pass it lables. Mean mass by sex w/ label

    my.frogs %>% 
  group_by(sex) %>%
  summarise(mass.mean = mean(mass))
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   sex    mass.mean
#>   <fct>      <dbl>
#> 1 female      2.20
#> 2 male        2.97

    You can lable thigns anything, eg “puppies”.

    my.frogs %>% 
  group_by(sex) %>%
  summarise(puppies = mean(mass))
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   sex    puppies
#>   <fct>    <dbl>
#> 1 female    2.20
#> 2 male      2.97

    You can pass any summari function to summarise. We can give it sd to get the sd of mass by sex.

    my.frogs %>% 
  group_by(sex) %>%
  summarise(mass.sd = sd(mass))
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   sex    mass.sd
#>   <fct>    <dbl>
#> 1 female    1.00
#> 2 male      1.37

    What makes dplyr::group_by and summarize() really powerful is that you can pass it multiple summary functions at the same time

    my.frogs %>% 
  group_by(sex) %>%
  summarise(mass.mean = mean(mass),
            mass.sd = sd(mass))
#> # A tibble: 2 x 3
#>   sex    mass.mean mass.sd
#>   <fct>      <dbl>   <dbl>
#> 1 female      2.20    1.00
#> 2 male        2.97    1.37

    dplyr has a handy function n() for getting your sample size.

    my.frogs %>% 
  group_by(sex) %>%
  summarise(mass.mean = mean(mass),
            mass.sd = sd(mass),
            n = n())
#> # A tibble: 2 x 4
#>   sex    mass.mean mass.sd     n
#>   <fct>      <dbl>   <dbl> <int>
#> 1 female      2.20    1.00    20
#> 2 male        2.97    1.37    20
    Pass it a novel function
    r my.frogs %>% group_by(sex) %>% summarise(mass.mean = my_sd1(mass)) #> # A tibble: 2 x 2 #> sex mass.mean #> <fct> <dbl> #> 1 female 0.224 #> 2 male 0.306

    Alternatives

    doBy::summaryBy

    The doBy package has a nice syntax. I don’t really see manhy people use it

    library(doBy)
summaryBy(mass ~ sex,data = my.frogs, FUN = mean)

summaryBy(mass ~ sex,data = my.frogs, FUN = c(mean,sd))

    tapply()

    tapply is pretty old school

    tapply(X = my.frogs$mass,INDEX = my.frogs$sex, FUN = mean)
#> female   male 
#> 2.2025 2.9680

    reshape2::dcast

    What I’ve used most of my career thus far. Am slowly switch to dplyr.

    library(reshape2)
dcast(data = my.frogs,
      formula = sex ~ .,
      value.var = "mass",
      fun.aggregate  = mean)
#>      sex      .
#> 1 female 2.2025
#> 2   male 2.9680
